verses.text: These \add are\add* also proverbs of Solomon , which the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied out. \p
\add It is\add* the glory of God to conceal a thing : but the honour of kings \add is\add* to search out a matter.
The heaven for height , and the earth for depth , and the heart of kings \add is\add* unsearchable.\f + \fr 25.3 \ft is…: Heb. there is no searching\f* \p
Take away the dross from the silver , and there shall come forth a vessel for the finer.
Take away the wicked \add from\add* before the king , and his throne shall be established in righteousness. \p
Put not forth thyself in the presence of the king , and stand not in the place of great \add men:\add*\f + \fr 25.6 \ft Put…: Heb. Set not out thy glory\f*
For better \add it is\add* that it be said unto thee, Come up hither; than that thou shouldest be put lower in the presence of the prince whom thine eyes have seen. \p
Go not forth hastily to strive , lest \add thou know not\add* what to do in the end thereof, when thy neighbour hath put thee to shame.
Debate thy cause with thy neighbour \add himself;\add* and discover not a secret to another :\f + \fr 25.9 \ft a secret…: or, the secret of\f*
Lest he that heareth \add it\add* put thee to shame , and thine infamy turn not away. \p
A word fitly spoken \add is like\add* apples of gold in pictures of silver.\f + \fr 25.11 \ft fitly…: Heb. spoken upon his wheels\f*
\add As\add* an earring of gold , and an ornament of fine gold , \add so is\add* a wise reprover upon an obedient ear.
As the cold of snow in the time of harvest , \add so is\add* a faithful messenger to them that send him: for he refresheth the soul of his masters.
Whoso boasteth himself of a false gift \add is like\add* clouds and wind without rain.\f + \fr 25.14 \ft of a…: Heb. in a gift of falsehood\f*
By long forbearing is a prince persuaded , and a soft tongue breaketh the bone.
Hast thou found honey ? eat so much as is sufficient for thee, lest thou be filled therewith, and vomit it.

Withdraw thy foot from thy neighbour’s house ; lest he be weary of thee, and \add so\add* hate thee.\f + \fr 25.17 \ft Withdraw…: or, Let thy foot be seldom in\f*\f + \fr 25.17 \ft weary…: Heb. full of thee\f*
A man that beareth false witness against his neighbour \add is\add* a maul , and a sword , and a sharp arrow.
Confidence in an unfaithful man in time of trouble \add is like\add* a broken tooth , and a foot out of joint.
\add As\add* he that taketh away a garment in cold weather , \add and as\add* vinegar upon nitre , so \add is\add* he that singeth songs to an heavy heart. \p
If thine enemy be hungry , give him bread to eat ; and if he be thirsty , give him water to drink :
For thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head , and the \nd \+w LORD|strong="H3068"\+w*\nd* shall reward thee.
The north wind driveth away rain : so \add doth\add* an angry countenance a backbiting tongue.\f + \fr 25.23 \ft driveth…: or, bringeth forth rain: so doth a backbiting tongue an angry countenance\f*
\add It is\add* better to dwell in the corner of the housetop , than with a brawling woman and in a wide house.
\add As\add* cold waters to a thirsty soul , so \add is\add* good news from a far country.
A righteous man falling down before the wicked \add is as\add* a troubled fountain , and a corrupt spring.
\add It is\add* not good to eat much honey : so \add for men\add* to search their own glory \add is not\add* glory.
He that \add hath\add* no rule over his own spirit \add is like\add* a city \add that is\add* broken down , \add and\add* without walls.
